title: Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours to nearly round-the-clock
summary: STORY: :: FileThe Nasdaq is seeking to roll out near round-the-clock trading of stocks.The stock exchange is one of the world’s largest and home to tech heavyweights Nvidia, Apple and Amazon.It plans to file paperwork to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to expand trading hours from 16 hours a day to 23 hours a day, five days a week.Nasdaq’s plans would see its trading week kick off on Sunday at 9 p.m. Eastern and end Friday at 8 p.m.:: FileA trading day would be split into two sessions with an hour break at 8 p.m. for maintenance, then start back up at 9 p.m., and would still feature opening and closing bells.It follows plans announced both by the New York Stock Exchange and Cboe Global Markets for those exchanges to move to nonstop five-day-a-week trading.Investor demand for nonstop trading of U.S. stocks has surged in recent years.That’s led regulators to introduce new rules and allow proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond traditional market hours.Today the U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies around the globe……and foreign holdings of U.S. equities hit $17 trillion last year, according to Nasdaq data.Advocates for moving closer to 24/7 trading argue it will allow investors, especially those outside the U.S., to react more quickly to events that happen outside regular market hours.Major Wall Street banks are cautious about the push, pointing to anxiety over lower liquidity, more volatility, and uncertainty over returns on investment.

raw.headline: Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours to nearly round-the-clock
raw.summary: STORY: :: FileThe Nasdaq is seeking to roll out near round-the-clock trading of stocks.The stock exchange is one of the world’s largest and home to tech heavyweights Nvidia, Apple and Amazon.It plans to file paperwork to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to expand trading hours from 16 hours a day to 23 hours a day, five days a week.Nasdaq’s plans would see its trading week kick off on Sunday at 9 p.m. Eastern and end Friday at 8 p.m.:: FileA trading day would be split into two sessions with an hour break at 8 p.m. for maintenance, then start back up at 9 p.m., and would still feature opening and closing bells.It follows plans announced both by the New York Stock Exchange and Cboe Global Markets for those exchanges to move to nonstop five-day-a-week trading.Investor demand for nonstop trading of U.S. stocks has surged in recent years.That’s led regulators to introduce new rules and allow proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond traditional market hours.Today the U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies around the globe……and foreign holdings of U.S. equities hit $17 trillion last year, according to Nasdaq data.Advocates for moving closer to 24/7 trading argue it will allow investors, especially those outside the U.S., to react more quickly to events that happen outside regular market hours.Major Wall Street banks are cautious about the push, pointing to anxiety over lower liquidity, more volatility, and uncertainty over returns on investment.

title: Exclusive-Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours, as Wall Street gears up for 24/7 move
summary: Nasdaq, one of the world's largest exchanges that is home to tech companies Nvidia, Apple and Amazon, is planning to submit paperwork with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday to roll out round-the-clock trading of stocks, as it looks to capitalize on a global demand for U.S. ​equities.  Investor demand for nonstop trading in U.S. stocks has surged in recent years, prompting regulators to introduce new rules and green-light proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond ‌normal market hours.  The U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies globally, while total foreign holdings of U.S. equities reached $17 trillion last year, according to data compiled by Nasdaq.

raw.headline: Exclusive-Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours, as Wall Street gears up for 24/7 move
raw.summary: Nasdaq, one of the world's largest exchanges that is home to tech companies Nvidia, Apple and Amazon, is planning to submit paperwork with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday to roll out round-the-clock trading of stocks, as it looks to capitalize on a global demand for U.S. ​equities.  Investor demand for nonstop trading in U.S. stocks has surged in recent years, prompting regulators to introduce new rules and green-light proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond ‌normal market hours.  The U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies globally, while total foreign holdings of U.S. equities reached $17 trillion last year, according to data compiled by Nasdaq.

title: Nvidia buys AI software provider SchedMD to expand open-source AI push
summary: Nvidia said on Monday it acquired AI software firm SchedMD, as the chip designer doubles down on open-source technology ​and steps up investments in the artificial intelligence ecosystem to fend off ‌rising competition.  The chip designer built its reputation on speedy chips, but it also offers a range ‌of its own AI models, from physics simulations to self-driving vehicles, as open-source software that researchers and companies can use.  Nvidia shares were up 1.35% after the news and an earlier announcement of new open-source AI models.

title: Warner Bros. Is Blockbuster Finale to $4.5 Trillion M&A Haul
summary: Paramount Skydance Corp.’s hostile bid to snatch Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. from under the nose of Netflix Inc. encapsulates the themes that have shaped a banner year for mergers and acquisitions: renewed desire for transformative tie-ups, massive checks from Wall Street, the flow of Middle East money and US President Donald Trump’s role as both disruptor and dealmaker.  Global transaction values have risen around 40% to about $4.5 trillion this year, data compiled by Bloomberg show, as companies chase ultra-ambitious combinations, emboldened by friendlier regulators.  “There’s a sentiment in boardrooms and among CEOs that this is a potential multi-year window where it’s possible to dream big,” said Ben Wallace, co-head of Americas M&A at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. “We’re at the beginning of a rate-cutting cycle so there’s anticipation that there will be more liquidity.”

raw.headline: Warner Bros. Is Blockbuster Finale to $4.5 Trillion M&A Haul
raw.summary: Paramount Skydance Corp.’s hostile bid to snatch Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. from under the nose of Netflix Inc. encapsulates the themes that have shaped a banner year for mergers and acquisitions: renewed desire for transformative tie-ups, massive checks from Wall Street, the flow of Middle East money and US President Donald Trump’s role as both disruptor and dealmaker.  Global transaction values have risen around 40% to about $4.5 trillion this year, data compiled by Bloomberg show, as companies chase ultra-ambitious combinations, emboldened by friendlier regulators.  “There’s a sentiment in boardrooms and among CEOs that this is a potential multi-year window where it’s possible to dream big,” said Ben Wallace, co-head of Americas M&A at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. “We’re at the beginning of a rate-cutting cycle so there’s anticipation that there will be more liquidity.”

title: Hesai Recognized as the Only Lidar Company on Morgan Stanley's "Humanoid Tech 25" of Global Robotics Leaders
summary: Hesai Technology (NASDAQ: HSAI; HKEX: 2525), a global leader in lidar solutions, has been named to Morgan Stanley's "Humanoid Tech 25", an exclusive list of the world's 25 most influential robotics companies. Hesai is the only lidar company included on the shortlist, recognized for delivering critical 3D perception capabilities that enable real-world robotics applications. Other companies featured on the Humanoid Tech 25 list include industry leaders such as NVIDIA, AMD, Sony, Samsung, Onsemi, H

title: 'I'm Always In A State Of Anxiety' Says Nvidia CEO As $5T Triumph Still Feels Like '30 Days From Going Out Of Business'
summary: A towering valuation hasn't softened the fears of a CEO who says the company still feels close to collapse. That outlook never changed, Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang said recently. Huang told "The Joe Rogan Experience" podcast that the pressure begins at 4 a.m. every day, when he starts checking emails and added that he works seven days a week, including holidays. He said Nvidia's scale has not altered how he prepares for sudden shifts in the industry. Don't Miss: Missed Nvidia and Tesla

raw.headline: 'I'm Always In A State Of Anxiety' Says Nvidia CEO As $5T Triumph Still Feels Like '30 Days From Going Out Of Business'
raw.summary: A towering valuation hasn't softened the fears of a CEO who says the company still feels close to collapse. That outlook never changed, Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang said recently. Huang told "The Joe Rogan Experience" podcast that the pressure begins at 4 a.m. every day, when he starts checking emails and added that he works seven days a week, including holidays. He said Nvidia's scale has not altered how he prepares for sudden shifts in the industry. Don't Miss: Missed Nvidia and Tesla
